awd_titl_txt: STEM TRansfer Students Opportunity for Nurtured Growth (STRONG)
awd_abstract_narration:
With funding from the National Science Foundation's Scholarships in Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (S-STEM) program, the STEM TRansfer Students Opportunity for Nurtured Growth (STRONG) is providing support to low-income students with demonstrated financial need and academic promise to succeed in STEM disciplines at the University of Central Florida (UCF). This S-STEM Track 2 project is funding up to 36 scholarships over 5 years for transfer students who are pursuing bachelor's degrees in STEM. Compared to first time in college (FTIC) students who begin their academic careers at a four-year institution, transfer students generally find the path to obtaining a bachelor's degree more challenging, and they are significantly less likely to graduate than their FTIC counterparts. Finding ways to improve the educational experiences of these students is an urgent national priority.  The aim of UCF's STRONG project is to substantially increase retention, graduation rates, and career success of STEM transfer students.  This goal is achieved in part by giving each student a role in various STEM activities within a community of high-achieving scholars, who are majoring in similar fields.  Providing financial support, mentorship, and opportunities for academic engagement outside the classroom promises to reduce the obstacles students face, keep them interested in their field of study, and motivate them to excel academically.  A thorough study of how the program affects its participants will maximize the impact of the intervention and informs future efforts to improve the educational experiences of STEM transfer students.

The UCF STRONG project consists of three components, which are all essential for reaching the program goal of increasing retention, graduation rates, and career success of STEM transfers. The first component is to design, implement, and improve a high-accuracy prediction model for identifying high-risk STEM transfers. Using known information about transfers, along with statistical analysis and machine learning, it will establish a means of predicting which students are least likely to complete a STEM degree, thereby helping UCF to know which students will benefit most from STRONG. The second component is to increase retention of transfers in STEM fields. STRONG scholars will be selected from financially needy incoming transfers who have been predicted to be unlikely to graduate, with the purpose of retaining them through graduation due to their participation in STRONG. This outcome is an expected result of increased student success through stimulation of academic integration and a cultivation of proficiency in their chosen fields.  More specifically, each student is given a role within a community of like-minded students from closely related fields; they also meet regularly with mentors and participate in STEM activities that promote their success.  The third component is to learn how the interventions influence STEM transfer students' ability to become active participants in their own learning. The project team will study the effects of the intervention on metacognition, motivation, and behavior, which are the three pillars of Self-Regulated Learning and are essential for student success.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

inst.inst_name: The University of Central Florida Board of Trustees
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE UNIVERSITY OF CENTRAL FLORIDA BOARD OF TRUSTEES

por.por_cntn:
1. Common to public universities across the nation, transfer students in STEM fields are about 20% less likely to graduate than other students. The new environment, that has different standards and operates differently from the previous institution, along with demands to work long hours to meet financial needs and less engagement in university or career related activities, all contribute to the obstacles transfer students face on the path to a degree. The STRONG program at the University of Central Florida supported academically talented STEM transfer students, who were at risk of not completing a degree, through these critical challenges, starting in their first year at the university.

  2. STRONG scholarships provided students the freedom to focus on their studies, as they did not need to work an extra job to pay expenses. The program also provided faculty and peer mentors for each student, and they were immediately integrated into a small communities through social events and regular group meetings. To build a sense of belonging and make students more competitive for career placement, they also participated in activities beyond their regular studies, such as academic competitions, seminar attendance, professional clubs, and research. Every year, the scholars shared their stories of academic struggle and success at an event attended by their peers, faculty, college deans, and even the president of the university. The STRONG Scholars have overcome significant obstacles on the road to their degrees, as the support of the program has helped increase their confidence, keep them on track, and provide strategies to handle the stresses of pursuing a STEM degree.

  3. Altogether, 47 students pursuing B.S. degrees in twelve different STEM disciplines (Chemistry, Computer Science, Mathematics, Physics, Statistics, and Engineering: Aerospace, Civil, Computer, Electrical, Environmental, Industrial, and Mechanical) were supported by the program. Of these students, 20 had internships, 17 participated in research projects, 2 have publications, 26 have graduated and have jobs in STEM fields or are pursuing STEM graduate degrees or both, and 14 scholars are still enrolled, expecting to graduate with STEM degrees. Seven scholars did not complete the program, but only five of these are not on track to complete a STEM degree, meaning the attrition rate was 14.9\%, which is significantly lower than the baseline of 34\%. Compared to a group of STRONG eligible students who were either not interested or not selected for the program, a higher percentage of STRONG Scholars either graduated or were still enrolled by project end (85% vs. 79%).

  4. As part of the project, we created a means of predicting students’ likelihood of completing a STEM degree, using known information about transfer students, along with statistical analysis and machine learning. This study, based on machine learning techniques, was purely academic and was not used in the student selection process. Test results show that the algorithm has 83% accuracy. Further development of the model and more data may provide useful evidence for developing targeted support structures for transfer students as individuals.

  5. Financial and intellectual support have both been identified as important factors in transfer student success. To understand how these types of support influence students’ ability to become active participants of their own learning, we studied the effects of the intervention on metacognition, motivation, and behavior. The Motivational Strategies for Learning Questionnaire was administered once when scholars entered the program and once as they exited, showing no significant difference in motivational belief. However, the results did show a statistically significant difference in self-regulated learning, providing some evidence for the program’s impact on student success.


Last Modified: 06/02/2023
Modified by: Brian Moore

Common 	to public universities across the nation, transfer students in STEM 	fields are about 20% less likely to graduate than other students.  	The new environment, that has different standards and operates 	differently from the previous institution, along with demands to 	work long hours to meet financial needs and less engagement in 	university or career related activities, all contribute to the 	obstacles transfer students face on the path to a degree.  The 	STRONG program at the University of Central Florida supported 	academically talented STEM transfer students, who were at risk of 	not completing a degree, through these critical challenges, starting 	in their first year at the university. 


STRONG 	scholarships provided students the freedom to focus on their 	studies, as they did not need to work an extra job to pay expenses.  	 The program also provided faculty and peer mentors for each 	student, and they were immediately integrated into a small 	communities through social events and regular group meetings.  To 	build a sense of belonging and make students more competitive for 	career placement, they also participated in activities beyond their 	regular studies, such as academic competitions, seminar attendance, 	professional clubs, and research.  Every year, the scholars shared 	their stories of academic struggle and success at an event attended 	by their peers, faculty, college deans, and even the president of 	the university.  The STRONG Scholars have overcome significant 	obstacles on the road to their degrees, as the support of the 	program has helped increase their confidence, keep them on track, 	and provide strategies to handle the stresses of pursuing a STEM 	degree. 


Altogether, 	 47 students pursuing B.S. 	degrees in twelve different STEM disciplines (Chemistry, Computer 	Science, Mathematics, Physics, Statistics, and Engineering: 	Aerospace, Civil, Computer, Electrical, Environmental, Industrial, 	and Mechanical) were supported by the program.   Of these students, 	20 had internships, 17 participated in research projects, 2 have 	publications, 26 have graduated and have jobs in STEM fields or are 	pursuing STEM graduate degrees or both, and 14 scholars are still 	enrolled, expecting to graduate with STEM degrees.  Seven scholars 	did not complete the program, but only five of these are not on 	track to complete a STEM degree, meaning the attrition rate was 	14.9\%, which is significantly lower than the baseline of 34\%.   	Compared to a group of STRONG eligible students who were either not 	interested or not selected for the program, a higher percentage of 	STRONG Scholars either graduated or were still enrolled by project 	end (85% vs. 79%).


As 	part of the project, we created a means of predicting students’ 	likelihood of completing a STEM degree, using known information 	about transfer students, along 	with statistical analysis and machine learning.  This study, based 	on machine learning techniques, was purely academic and was not used 	in the student selection process.  Test results show that the 	algorithm has 83% accuracy.  Further development of the model and 	more data may provide useful evidence for developing targeted 	support structures for transfer students as individuals. 


Financial 	and intellectual support have both been identified as important 	factors in transfer student success. To understand how these types 	of support influence students’ ability to become active 	participants of their own learning, we studied the effects of the 	intervention on metacognition, motivation, and behavior.  The 	Motivational Strategies for Learning Questionnaire was administered 	once when scholars entered the program and once as they exited, showing 	no significant difference in motivational 	belief.  However, the results did show a statistically significant difference in self-regulated 	learning, providing some evidence for the program’s impact on 	student success.
